Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Modeling, Simulation, and Validation for Tissue Transplantation
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental problem in tissue transplantation in reconstructive surgery is how to determine the size of tissue flap that can be transferred without the development of necrosis. An autologous tissue flap is a unit of tissue that is transferred from one site to another of the same patient while maintaining its own blood supply. Improved understanding of the anatomy of tissue blood supply combined with advances in instrumentation and surgical techniques has resulted in modern methods to transfer tissue based on single arteries and veins. Surgeons still rely on personal experience to make a qualitative assessment of the adequacy of blood supply when deciding the size of the flap. If unsuccessful, the blood supply will be inadequate for the amount of tissue transferred, and portions of the flap will not survive, wasting the whole surgery. This can result in significant postoperative complications, additional surgery, increased morbidity, and increased medical costs. It is therefore important to develop a practical tool to enable the most reliable flap design based on the adequacy of blood supply. In order to address this problem, this research project will develop robust mathematical models that allow estimating the diameter of the perforating artery and the level of oxygenation in a tissue given its size and shape.

The problem in hand is complicated and warrants a truly patient-specific approach. Modeling and simulations are necessary in multiple scales, i.e., at the perforator level, at the intermediate vascular network level, and at the capillary level. Validating the model with existing patient data is a challenge. The mismatch of the size of the blood vessel between the donor site and the recipient site creates additional problems. Based on these issues, the objective of this research is to create sophisticated computational tools for successful flap transfer. To achieve this goal, the specific research objectives are 1) to create a mathematical model to predict blood flow and oxygen supply in surgical flaps, 2) to generate data-driven simulation in vascular architecture and image-based validation in perforator flaps, and 3) to design the flap geometry based on (a) simulation results of blood flow and oxygen transport and (b) data clustering analysis of flap parameters from previous surgeries. The research project is a fundamental synergy of mathematical modeling, medical science, and surgery. The adopted interdisciplinary approach combines the expertise of the mathematical modeling community with that of radiologists and plastic surgeons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reconstructive surgery which restores the form and function of the body is a specialized form of plastic surgery that frequently involves moving a patient's own tissue from one location to another in discrete units known as surgical flaps. The goal of this funded research project was to develop computational tools to predict the flap survival in the context of reconstructive surgery. We introduced 'computational thinking' to assist a surgeon to take decisions regarding tissue transplantation. With this goal, the main aims of the project are, 1) to develop a multi-scale mathematical models to predict the blood flow and oxygen supply in surgical tissue flaps, 2) to generate data-driven simulations and validate the developed models with existing imaging modalities in perforator flaps, 3) to design optimized tissue flap geometries based on simulation results and data clustering based on tissue geometry and artery parameters.

Outcomes related to Intellectual Merits

The team focused on developing a multiscale mathematical model based on the homogenization approach to assessing the blood flow and oxygen flow in the tissue flaps. The flow of blood through the vasculature is treated as the flow of fluid through an isotropic porous medium. Although this is a simplified assumption concerning the capillary network, in the absence of detailed information about the geometry of the vasculature, these models provided a useful and tractable approximation of the true situation. Later, a Bayesian framework was introduced for uncertainty quantification in a bifurcating network of one-dimensional extensible arteries.

The more significant challenge in the project was to work with the 3D complex arterial network. In order to create data-driven simulations based on vascular architecture, shape recovery algorithms were needed. One of our main achievement in this funded project was to develop a new automated cross-sectional shape recovery technique of the 3D branching structures from the point cloud data from imaging modalities. This method can be used not only for biological anatomies but also for structural frames and non-monolithic geometries. The methodology is based on the automated recovery of cross-sectional shapes using centrally located curves by means of skeletonization, segmentation, fitting segment splines and filtering.

The second key achievement of the funded project was to create a new optimized methodology to find the critical paths for flow distribution in an arbitrary geometry. Since our ultimate goal was to develop an optimized flap geometry based on specific objective functions such as adequate blood flow and oxygen transfer; we took a topology optimization approach. In this regards, we developed novel topology optimization frameworks where different objective functions can be prescribed, and different geometric features can be set as constraints. Topology optimization gives the optimum flow path when subjected to a potential flow such as heat, blood flow. Our mathematical model was based on a diffusion model which is very similar to heat conduction equations. As our proof of concept of our topology optimization framework, we presented a conceptual design for efficient flow paths. This technology can be also used to design efficient heat exchangers.

Then, we developed a topology optimization framework which can mimic the complicated internal architecture of natural structures such as fungus, cactus fiber, mushroom, cancellous bone, and capillary architecture. In this framework, we can define objective functions and constraints to obtain the desired random patterns. The ratio of arteries compared to the overall perforator geometry as well as the perimeter of the arterial network affects the results. Additionally, we noticed that the target perimeter value and the pattern of the initial distribution play a vital role in obtaining the natural curvatures in the internal structures as well as avoiding excessive island patterns. From our study, we found that the volume fraction ratio and as well as the thickness and the perimeter play a significant role in the architecture of the arteries. We have also developed CFD simulations to measure the blood flow in the perforators.

Outcomes related to Broader Impacts

Creating a computational tool to guide the survivability of flap is novel. Topology optimization methods have been used to find the optimum paths of main arteries inside geometrically shaped flaps. The methods that were developed can be used in other research disciplines (e.g, cancellous bone, heat path design).

In this project we worked towards developing predicting computational tools that can save physical and mental trauma for reconstructive surgical patients who have deformities due to trauma or cancer resection. It will save tremendous costs by reducing the number of iterative surgeries and also improve the quality of life for the patients. 

In term of education, this funded project has been instrumental in developing a new discipline of research and education in computational surgery.
